senses.definition: embarrassed and ashamed because of something that you have done -ed

senses.definition: to hate something, for example a way of behaving or thinking, especially for moral reasons

senses.definition: extremely unpleasant and causing horror

senses.definition: to feel deep hate or horror for something/somebody
very interested in something/somebody so that you are not paying attention to anything else

senses.definition: the process of a liquid, gas or other substance being taken in

senses.definition: the process of a smaller group, country, etc. becoming part of a larger group or country

senses.definition: the fact of somebody being very interested in something so that it takes all their attention

senses.definition: unfair, cruel or violent treatment of somebody

senses.definition: rude and offensive remarks, usually made when somebody is very angry

senses.definition: angry bitter feelings or words

senses.definition: unable to stop using or doing something as a habit, especially something harmful

senses.definition: a feeling of great love or worship

senses.definition: to love somebody very much love

senses.definition: behind the score or position of your opponents

senses.definition: showing caring feelings and love for somebody Affectionate

an affectionate kiss

senses.definition: in a state of nervous excitement

senses.definition: a violent attack or threats by one person against another person or by one country against another country

senses.definition: developing quickly and difficult to treat

senses.definition: filled with horror and surprise when you see or hear something ghost

senses.definition: worry that you show by behaving in a nervous way

senses.definition: public protest in order to achieve political change

senses.definition: a public meeting or a march (= an organized walk by many people) at which people show that they are protesting against or supporting something

senses.definition: the act of mixing or shaking a liquid

senses.definition: a loud noise or a signal that warns people of danger or of a problem

senses.definition: a ringing sound or a tune played by a clock or your phone after you have set it to play at a particular time to wake you up

senses.definition: to fit something such as a door with a device that warns people when somebody is trying to enter illegally
anxious or afraid that something dangerous or unpleasant might happen afraid

senses.definition: protected by an alarm

senses.definition: without any other people Alone

senses.definition: without the help of other people or things

senses.definition: used after a noun or pronoun to emphasize one particular thing

senses.definition: a love affair, especially a secret one

senses.definition: the fact of being entertained by something

In the 1980s it began losing readers to other magazines such as Private Eye. It stopped appearing in 1992 but appeared again from 1996 to 2002.

Much to her embarrassment, she realized that everybody had been listening to her singing.

senses.definition: a situation that causes problems for somebody

examples.x: Her resignation will be a severe embarrassment to the party.

senses.definition: a person who causes problems for another person or other people and makes them feel embarrassed

examples.x: Poor Lucy! He's such an embarrassment to her.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel angry or disappointed about something over a long period of time

examples.x: Years of caring for her ageing parents had embittered her.
They were becoming deeply embittered by the government’s lack of concern.
What had embittered them most of all was their exclusion from the judicial process.

senses.definition: feeling angry or disappointed about something over a long period of time; showing this feeling

examples.x: a sick and embittered man
an embittered laugh

senses.definition: a strong feeling such as love, fear or anger; the part of a person’s character that consists of feelings British reserve

examples.x: to show/express your emotions
They expressed mixed emotions at the news.
Counselling can teach people to handle negative emotions such as fear and anger.
Fear is a normal human emotion.
This documentary manages to capture the raw emotions of life at the tough end.
Emotions are running high (= people are feeling very excited, angry, etc.).
She showed no emotion at the verdict.
The decision was based on emotion rather than rational thought.
Mary was overcome with emotion.

senses.definition: connected with people’s feelings (= with the emotions)

examples.x: emotional problems/stress
The emotional impact of the film is powerful and lasting.
He clearly feels an emotional connection to the place.
a child’s emotional and intellectual development
He tried his best to provide emotional support for them.
Physical and emotional well-being are inextricably linked.

senses.definition: causing people to feel strong emotions

examples.x: emotional language
abortion and other emotional issues
The anniversary of the accident was very emotional for him.
It was obviously an emotional moment for everyone involved.
This is a very emotional time for me.

senses.definition: showing strong emotions, sometimes in a way that other people think is unnecessary

examples.x: an emotional response/reaction
She was in a very emotional state.
He tends to get emotional on these occasions.
They made an emotional appeal for help.
Don't be so emotional about everything!

senses.definition: able to understand how somebody else feels because you can imagine what it is like to be that person

examples.x: an empathetic listener
His personal history makes him especially empathetic to workers' need for a fair wage.
The medical profession requires doctors to be both clinically competent and empathetic towards their patients.

senses.definition: in a way that shows you understand how somebody else feels because you can imagine what it would be like to be that person

examples.x: In order to build trust, you should make eye contact and listen empathetically.

senses.definition: a feeling of being sad because nothing seems to have any value

examples.x: There was an aching emptiness in her heart.

senses.definition: the fact that there is nothing or nobody in a place

examples.x: The silence and emptiness of the house did not scare her.

senses.definition: a place that is empty

examples.x: He stared out at the vast emptiness of the sea.

senses.definition: with no people or things inside

examples.x: an empty box/glass/bottle
empty hands (= not holding anything)
an empty plate (= with no food on it)
I noticed an empty space on the bookshelf.
I couldn't see any empty seats (= with nobody sitting in them).
The theatre was half empty.
an empty house/room/bus
As it got later, the streets became empty.
The house had been standing empty (= without people living in it) for some time.
It's not good to drink alcohol on an empty stomach (= without having eaten something).
The room was empty of furniture.

senses.definition: with no meaning; not meaning what is said

examples.x: empty words
an empty promise
Voters will see through the empty rhetoric.
an empty gesture aimed at pleasing the crowds

senses.definition: unhappy because life does not seem to have a purpose, usually after something sad has happened

examples.x: Three months after his death, she still felt empty.
My life seems empty without you.
We all feel very empty now she's gone.

senses.definition: without a quality that you would expect to be there

examples.x: words that were empty of meaning

senses.definition: liking something a lot

examples.x: He was less than enamoured of the music.
I'm not exactly enamoured with the idea of spending a whole day with them.

senses.definition: in love with somebody
to attract somebody strongly and make them feel very interested, excited, etc.

examples.x: The happy family scene had enchanted him.
The play continued to enchant all who watched it.

senses.definition: to place somebody/something under a magic spell (= magic words that have special powers)
so interested or involved in something that you give it all your attention

examples.x: Thankfully, they were all too engrossed to notice her.
She was engrossed in conversation.
Dawn was engrossed in stuffing clothes into a bag.

senses.definition: to get pleasure from something

examples.x: We thoroughly enjoyed our time in New York.
Thanks for a great evening. I really enjoyed it.
She seems to be enjoying life in Paris.
I enjoy playing tennis and squash.
I really enjoyed watching the film again.

senses.definition: to be happy and get pleasure from what you are doing

examples.x: They all enjoyed themselves at the party.
The kids all seemed to enjoy themselves.

senses.definition: to have something good that is an advantage to you

examples.x: People in this country enjoy a high standard of living.
He's always enjoyed good health.
Departmental managers enjoy considerable autonomy in the workplace.

senses.definition: used to say that you hope somebody gets pleasure from something that you are giving them or recommending to them

examples.x: Here's that book I promised you. Enjoy!

senses.definition: the pleasure that you get from something fun

examples.x: He spoiled my enjoyment of the game by talking all through it.

I get a lot of enjoyment from my grandchildren.
Do you get any enjoyment out of this type of work?

senses.definition: something that gives you pleasure

examples.x: Children like to share interests and enjoyments with their parents.

senses.definition: the fact of having and using something

examples.x: the enjoyment of equal rights

senses.definition: to make somebody very angry

examples.x: She was enraged at his stupidity.

senses.definition: to talk in an enthusiastic and excited way about something

examples.x: The article enthused about the benefits that the new system would bring.
‘It's a wonderful idea,’ he enthused.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel very interested and excited

examples.x: Everyone present was enthused by the idea.

senses.definition: a strong feeling of excitement and interest in something and a desire to become involved in it

examples.x: Her voice was full of enthusiasm.

Bella responded with great enthusiasm.
‘I don't mind,’ she said, without much enthusiasm.
The threat of violence did not dampen the enthusiasm of voters.
I can't say I share your enthusiasm for the idea.
He had a real enthusiasm for the work.
She never lost her enthusiasm for teaching.
He has shown little or no enthusiasm for regulating financial markets before now.

senses.definition: something that you are very interested in and spend a lot of time doing

examples.x: Reading is one of her many enthusiasms.

senses.definition: a person who is very interested in something and spends a lot of time doing it

examples.x: a football enthusiast
an enthusiast of jazz
She was an enthusiast for early Italian art.

senses.definition: a person who approves of something and shows enthusiasm for it

examples.x: enthusiasts for a united Europe
They are great enthusiasts of the American work ethic.

senses.definition: the feeling of wanting to be in the same situation as somebody else; the feeling of wanting something that somebody else has

examples.x: He couldn't conceal his envy of me.
She felt a pang of envy at the thought of his success.
They looked with envy at her latest purchase.
Her colleagues were green with envy (= they had very strong feelings of envy).

senses.definition: to wish you had the same qualities, possessions, opportunities, etc. as somebody else

examples.x: He envied her—she seemed to have everything she could possibly want.
She has always envied my success.
I envied him his good looks.
I secretly envied her for her good looks.
I envy you having such a close family.

senses.definition: to be glad that you do not have to do what somebody else has to do

examples.x: It's a difficult situation you're in. I don't envy you.
I don't envy her that job.

senses.definition: extremely annoyed, especially if you cannot do anything to improve the situation Exasperated

examples.x: ‘Why won't you answer me?’ he asked in an exasperated voice.
She was becoming exasperated with all the questions they were asking.

senses.definition: likely to become easily excited

examples.x: She had trouble controlling the class of excitable ten-year-olds.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel very pleased, interested or enthusiastic, especially about something that is going to happen

examples.x: The prospect of a year in India greatly excited her.

senses.definition: to make somebody nervous or upset and unable to relax

examples.x: Try not to excite your baby too much before bedtime.
Don't excite yourself (= keep calm).

senses.definition: to make somebody feel a particular emotion or react in a particular way

examples.x: to excite attention/curiosity/admiration
The news has certainly excited comment (= made people talk about it).
The advertising campaign failed to excite much interest in consumers.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel sexual desire
to make a part of the body or part of a physical system more active

examples.x: The energy of an electron is sufficient to excite the atom.

senses.definition: feeling or showing happiness and enthusiasm excited

examples.x: Staff got excited when they heard they were getting a bonus.
I am really excited about the opportunity to work with her.
The children were excited about opening their presents.
I'm really excited at the prospect of working abroad.
She was very excited at becoming a great aunt.
Don't get too excited by the sight of your name in print.
I'm so excited for you!
I woke up bright and early, excited for the day ahead.
She was very excited to be asked to play for Wales.
He is very excited that he will get to meet his idol.
The new restaurant is nothing to get excited about (= not particularly good).
An excited crowd of people gathered around her.

senses.definition: nervous or upset and unable to relax

examples.x: Some horses become excited when they're in traffic.

senses.definition: feeling sexual desire
the state of feeling or showing happiness and enthusiasm

examples.x: The news caused great excitement among her friends.
The sport needs new stars to generate excitement.
to feel a surge/thrill/shiver of excitement
There's a genuine sense of excitement because there is a British player in the final.
He did not share their excitement about the project.
I could hardly contain my excitement about going with Brandon.
She told of her excitement at the prospect of a new career as a pilot.
He was unable to control his excitement at hearing this.
I can remember the excitement of winning that game.
The app enables users to experience the excitement of space exploration.
You'll jump up from your seat with excitement.
The dog leapt and wagged its tail in excitement.
In her excitement she dropped her glass.

senses.definition: something that you find exciting

examples.x: The new job was not without its excitements.

senses.definition: the state of feeling sexual desire
expressing surprise or strong feelings
very tired

examples.x: I'm exhausted!
to feel completely/utterly exhausted
The exhausted climbers were rescued by helicopter.

senses.definition: completely used or finished

examples.x: You cannot grow crops on exhausted land.
financially exhausted countries

senses.definition: making you feel very tired

examples.x: an exhausting day at work
I find her exhausting—she never stops talking.

senses.definition: the state of being very tired

examples.x: suffering from physical/mental/nervous exhaustion
Her face was grey with exhaustion.

senses.definition: the act of using something until it is completely finished

examples.x: the exhaustion of natural resources

senses.definition: to make somebody feel very happy and excited

examples.x: Speed had always exhilarated him.

senses.definition: very happy and excited excited

examples.x: I felt exhilarated after a morning of skiing.
She felt exhilarated with the speed and the rush of air.

senses.definition: a feeling of being very happy and excited

examples.x: the exhilaration of performing on stage

senses.definition: to burst (= break apart) or make something burst loudly and violently, causing damage explode

examples.x: A second bomb exploded in a crowded market.
The firework exploded in his hand.
Bomb disposal experts exploded the device under controlled conditions.
There was a huge bang as if someone had exploded a rocket outside.

senses.definition: to suddenly become very angry or dangerous

examples.x: Tension between the two sides could explode at any time.
Suddenly Charles exploded with rage.
The protest exploded into a riot.
‘Of course there's something wrong!’ Jem exploded.

senses.definition: to suddenly express an emotion

examples.x: We all exploded into wild laughter.

senses.definition: to suddenly and quickly do something; to move suddenly with a lot of force

examples.x: After ten minutes the game exploded into life.
He suddenly exploded into action.

senses.definition: to make a sudden very loud noise

examples.x: Thunder exploded overhead.

senses.definition: to increase suddenly and very quickly in number

examples.x: the exploding world population

senses.definition: to show that something is not true, especially something that people believe

examples.x: This study explodes the myth that history graduates mainly become history teachers.
The report explodes the theory that there was a conspiracy.

senses.definition: easily able or likely to explode

examples.x: an explosive device (= a bomb)
an explosive mixture of chemicals
Hydrogen is highly explosive.

senses.definition: likely to cause violence or strong feelings of anger or hate

examples.x: one of the most explosive issues of our time

senses.definition: often having sudden violent or angry feelings

examples.x: an explosive temper

senses.definition: increasing suddenly and rapidly

examples.x: the explosive growth of the export market

senses.definition: sudden and loud

examples.x: There was an explosive crash and then everything fell silent.

senses.definition: to feel and show that you are very excited and happy because of something that has happened

examples.x: He leaned back, exulting at the success of his plan.
‘We won!’ she exulted.

senses.definition: feeling or showing that you are very proud or happy, especially because of something exciting that has happened

examples.x: The fans were exultant at their team’s victory.

senses.definition: to not be successful in achieving something

examples.x: Many diets fail because they are boring.

a policy/plan fails

He failed in his bid for the presidency.
The department failed to meet its sales targets.

The song can't fail to be a hit (= definitely will be a hit).

senses.definition: to not pass a test or an exam; to decide that somebody/something has not passed a test or an exam

examples.x: What will you do if you fail?

Students who fail the exam can retake it.

The restaurant failed a hygiene inspection.
The examiners failed over half the candidates.

senses.definition: to not do something

examples.x: People failed to recognize her talent.

Such comments never failed to annoy him.
I fail to see (= I don't understand) why you won't even give it a try.
She cannot fail to (= must) be aware of the situation.
They failed in their duty to protect the public.

senses.definition: to stop working

examples.x: The brakes on my bike failed half way down the hill.
The air-conditioning system failed on the hottest day of the year.
Sadly, his kidneys had failed.

senses.definition: to become weak

examples.x: Her eyesight is failing.
The light began to fail.

senses.definition: to disappoint somebody; to be unable to help when needed

examples.x: When he lost his job, he felt he had failed his family.
She tried to be brave, but her courage failed her.
Words fail me (= I cannot express how I feel).

senses.definition: to not be enough when needed or expected

examples.x: The crops failed again last summer.
The rains had failed and the rivers were dry.

senses.definition: to be unable to continue

examples.x: Several banks failed during the recession.

senses.definition: the state of feeling weak and tired and likely to become unconscious

examples.x: The side effects include nausea and faintness.

senses.definition: to be strongly attracted to somebody; to fall in love with somebody

examples.x: They fell for each other instantly.

senses.definition: very hungry

examples.x: When's lunch? I'm famished!
famished refugees

senses.definition: to want something or want to do something

examples.x: Fancy a drink?
I fancied a change of scene.
She didn't fancy (= did not like) the idea of going home in the dark.
Do you fancy going out this evening?

senses.definition: to be sexually attracted to somebody

examples.x: I think she fancies me.

senses.definition: to think that you are very popular, attractive or intelligent

examples.x: He started to chat to me and I could tell that he really fancied himself.

senses.definition: to like the idea of being something or to believe, often wrongly, that you are something

examples.x: She fancies herself (as) a serious actress.

senses.definition: used to show that you are surprised or shocked by something

examples.x: Fancy! She's never been in a plane before.

‘She remembered my name after all those years.’ ‘Fancy that!’

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something will win or be successful at something, especially in a race

examples.x: Which horse do you fancy in the next race?
He's hoping to get the job but I don't fancy his chances.

senses.definition: to believe or imagine something

examples.x: She fancied (that) she could hear footsteps.

senses.definition: feeling happy about something glad

examples.x: You're coming? I'm so pleased.

The boss should be pleased with you.
She seemed pleased at our success.
You're looking very pleased about something.
I'm very pleased for you both.
I'm really pleased (that) you're feeling better.

senses.definition: happy or willing to do something

examples.x: We are always pleased to be able to help.

Pleased to meet you (= said when you are introduced to somebody).

senses.definition: very interested

examples.x: The children watched, fascinated, as the picture began to appear.

senses.definition: a very strong attraction, that makes something very interesting

examples.x: London has a fascination all of its own.

senses.definition: the state of being very attracted to and interested in somebody/something fascination with

examples.x: The girls listened in fascination as the story unfolded.

the public’s enduring fascination with the Royal Family
She shared his fascination for motorbikes.

senses.definition: a feeling of being extremely tired, usually because of hard work or exercise

examples.x: physical and mental fatigue
Driver fatigue was to blame for the accident.
I was dropping with fatigue and could not keep my eyes open.

senses.definition: a feeling of not wanting to do a particular activity any longer because you have done too much of it

examples.x: Launching too many charity appeals risks bringing on compassion fatigue (= a loss of the ability to feel pity for other people’s suffering).
The city has lived with masks and restrictions for over a year and people are experiencing pandemic fatigue.

senses.definition: weakness in metal or wood caused by repeated bending or stretching

examples.x: The wing of the plane showed signs of metal fatigue.

senses.definition: loose clothes worn by soldiers

examples.x: soldiers in combat fatigues

senses.definition: duties, such as cleaning and cooking, that soldiers have to do, especially as a punishment

examples.x: We were all put on cookhouse fatigues for a week.

senses.definition: very tired, either physically, mentally or both

examples.x: The troops were already fatigued from the long forced march.

senses.definition: to be frightened of somebody/something or frightened of doing something

examples.x: All his employees fear him.

to fear death/persecution/the unknown

propaganda designed to make us hate and fear the enemy
Don't worry, you have nothing to fear from us.

senses.definition: to feel that something bad might have happened or might happen in the future

examples.x: She has been missing for three days now and police are beginning to fear the worst (= think that she is dead).

senses.definition: to be worried about somebody/something

examples.x: We fear for his safety.

senses.definition: nervous and afraid

fearful of an attack

senses.definition: terrible and frightening
extremely bad

examples.x: We made a fearful mess of the room.

senses.definition: making people feel very frightened Fearsome

a fearsome expression/sight

senses.definition: nervous, excited and very active

senses.definition: caused by fever (= a high temperature)

senses.definition: to experience a particular feeling or emotion

examples.x: The bus ride made me feel sick.

I feel as if nobody cares.
She felt as though she was going to cry.
to feel an idiot/a fool

senses.definition: to notice or be aware of something because it is touching you or having a physical effect on you

examples.x: I could feel the warm sun on my back.

He felt a hand on his shoulder.

examples.x: This situation doesn't feel right.

7 into 15 won’t go.

senses.definition: to combine well with something

examples.x: Does this jacket go with this skirt?

senses.definition: used to talk about what tune or words a song or poem has or what happens in a story

senses.definition: to say

examples.x: I asked ‘How much?’ and he goes, ‘Fifty’ and I go, ‘Fifty? You must be joking!’

senses.definition: to start an activity

examples.x: I'll say ‘One, two, three, go!’ as a signal for you to start.

senses.definition: if a machine goes, it works goes

senses.definition: used to talk about wanting to get rid of somebody/something

examples.x: The old sofa will have to go.

senses.definition: to get worse; to become damaged or stop working correctly

examples.x: Her sight is beginning to go.

senses.definition: to die. People say ‘go’ to avoid saying ‘die’.

examples.x: I don't know where the money goes!

senses.definition: to be sold

examples.x: We won't let the house go for less than $200 000.

senses.definition: to be willing to pay a particular amount of money for something

examples.x: He's offered £3 000 for the car and I don't think he'll go any higher.

senses.definition: to help; to play a part in doing something

examples.x: This all goes to prove my theory.

senses.definition: to be available

examples.x: There just aren't any jobs going in this area.

senses.definition: to use a toilet

senses.definition: when a performer goes on, they begin their performance goes on

senses.definition: to join a team as a substitute during a game

examples.x: Maguire went on in place of Cahill just before half-time.

senses.definition: when a light, the electricity, etc. goes on, it starts to work goes on

examples.x: Suddenly all the lights went on.

senses.definition: to pass

examples.x: She became more and more talkative as the evening went on.

senses.definition: to happen

examples.x: What's going on here?

senses.definition: if a situation goes on, it continues without changing goes on

senses.definition: to continue speaking, often after stopping for a short time

examples.x: She hesitated for a moment and then went on.

senses.definition: used to encourage somebody to do something

examples.x: Go on! Have another drink!

senses.definition: a condition in which there are raised spots on your skin because you feel cold, frightened or excited

examples.x: It gave me goose pimples just to think about it.

senses.definition: to eat a lot of something, until you are too full to eat any more
available to do what you want with rather than work

examples.x: He's studying music in his spare time.

senses.definition: that is not being used or is not needed at the present time

examples.x: We've got a spare bedroom, if you'd like to stay.

senses.definition: kept in case you need to replace the one you usually use; extra

examples.x: a spare key/tyre

senses.definition: thin, and usually quite tall
the structure that covers or forms the top of a building or vehicle

examples.x: a flat/sloping/pitched roof

a tin/slate/tiled/thatched roof
The corner of the classroom was damp where the roof had leaked.

The roof of the car was not damaged in the accident.
Offices on the upper floors have access to a roof terrace.

senses.definition: having the type of roof mentioned

examples.x: flat-roofed buildings

senses.definition: the top of an underground space such as a tunnel or cave

examples.x: The roof of the tunnel was starting to collapse.

senses.definition: the top of the inside of your mouth
to take or hold somebody/something with your hand suddenly or roughly

examples.x: She grabbed his arm as he got up to leave.

Someone grabbed me from behind.

senses.definition: to take a picture from a television or video film, or from a computer screen, and store it as an image on a computer

examples.x: You can use this keyboard shortcut to grab part of the screen.

senses.definition: feeling or showing thanks because somebody has done something kind for you or has done as you asked

senses.definition: serious in manner, as if something sad or important has just happened

senses.definition: a strong desire for more wealth, possessions, power, etc. than a person needs

senses.definition: a strong desire for more food or drink when you are no longer hungry or thirsty

senses.definition: wanting more money, power, food, etc. than you really need Greedy

senses.definition: feeling extremely sad because of something that has happened, especially the death of somebody

senses.definition: weak and unable to think or move well because you are ill or very tired

senses.definition: something horrible

senses.definition: horrible

senses.definition: extremely sad or disappointed

senses.definition: a condition in which somebody experiences violent or extreme emotions that they cannot control, especially as a result of shock

senses.definition: wild laughter

senses.definition: a person or thing that is loved and admired very much idle

senses.definition: a statue that is worshipped as a god

senses.definition: having or showing too much love or praise for somebody/something

senses.definition: the practice of worshipping statues as gods

senses.definition: a happy and peaceful place, event or experience, especially one connected with the countryside

senses.definition: public shame and loss of honour

senses.definition: angry and rude or annoyed, especially when this seems unreasonable

senses.definition: to shine light on something

senses.definition: to make something clearer or easier to understand

senses.definition: to decorate a street, building, etc. with bright lights for a special occasion

senses.definition: to make a person’s face, etc. seem bright and excited

senses.definition: in a bad mood, especially because somebody has annoyed or upset you

senses.definition: red, painful and hot because of infection or injury painful

examples.x: Is it that wretched woman again?

senses.definition: showing that you think something is funny but also disappointing or annoying

examples.x: ‘At least we got one vote,’ she said with a wry smile.
He pulled a wry face when I asked him how it had gone.

senses.definition: funny in a way that shows irony

examples.x: It's a wry comedy about family life.
a wry comment
He didn't even seem to notice her wry humour.
The film takes a wry look at the British class system.
